articles.headline: Family Separation May Have Hit Thousands More Migrant Children Than Reported
articles.snippet: The government has said that about 2,700 migrant children were separated from their families at the border last year. But the removals may have involved thousands more.
articles.abstract: The government has said that about 2,700 migrant children were separated from their families at the border last year. But the removals may have involved thousands more.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Trump administration most likely separated thousands more children from their parents at the Southern border than was previously believed, according to a report by government inspectors released on Thursday.

articles.headline: Trump Hits Back at Pelosi, Upending Her Trip to See Troops
articles.snippet: The House speaker had threatened to cancel President Trump’s State of the Union address, citing security concerns because of the government shutdown.
articles.abstract: The House speaker had threatened to cancel President Trump’s State of the Union address, citing security concerns because of the government shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bus emblazoned with the United States Air Force logo was idling outside the Capitol on Thursday, members of Congress on board, ready to depart for Joint Base Andrews and a waiting military aircraft. Inside, Speaker Nancy Pelosi was in her office making final preparations to lead the congressional delegation on a secret visit to American troops in Afghanistan with a stop in Brussels.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Annie Karni and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: 3 Officers Acquitted of Covering Up for Colleague in Laquan McDonald Killing
articles.snippet: Along with the three officers, the broad concept of a police “code of silence” was on trial in Chicago.
articles.abstract: Along with the three officers, the broad concept of a police “code of silence” was on trial in Chicago.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Three Chicago police officers were acquitted on Thursday of charges that they had conspired and lied to protect a white police officer who fired 16 deadly shots into a black teenager, a contentious verdict in a case over what many viewed as a “code of silence” in the Police Department.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Monica Davey

articles.headline: PG&E Bankruptcy Could Deal Blow to Its Solar-Power Suppliers’ Finances
articles.snippet: The California utility promises that its customers’ lights will stay on if it files for bankruptcy this month, but companies that supply it with electricity might have more to worry about.
articles.abstract: The California utility promises that its customers’ lights will stay on if it files for bankruptcy this month, but companies that supply it with electricity might have more to worry about.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Pacific Gas and Electric promises that its customers’ lights will stay on if it follows through on plans to file for bankruptcy this month. But companies that supply the California utility’s electricity may have more to worry about.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: The Things John Bogle Taught Us: Humility, Ethics and Simplicity
articles.snippet: Personal finance luminaries and everyday investors share lessons from the late Vanguard founder.
articles.abstract: Personal finance luminaries and everyday investors share lessons from the late Vanguard founder.
articles.lead_paragraph: So many people have John Bogle stories.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: At Los Angeles Teachers’ Strike, a Rallying Cry: More Funding, Fewer Charters
articles.snippet: The teachers’ union is highlighting what it sees as the growing problem of charter schools, saying that they siphon off students and money from traditional public schools.
articles.abstract: The teachers’ union is highlighting what it sees as the growing problem of charter schools, saying that they siphon off students and money from traditional public schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Maria Lopez had to rush off for her job at a nearby laundromat. Carmen Vasquez did not want her son to ruin his perfect attendance and needed to get to the home across town where she cleans a couple of times a week. Aurelia Aguilar needed to get to the restaurant where she cooks and serves.

articles.headline: Washington as Unruly Sandbox: Squabbles, Antics and Tantrums
articles.snippet: As the shutdown drags on, Trump-like behavior proliferates. The president “does generally force people to play down to his level,’’ says a biographer.
articles.abstract: As the shutdown drags on, Trump-like behavior proliferates. The president “does generally force people to play down to his level,’’ says a biographer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a week of White House tantrums and fast-food dinners, of canceled speeches and aborted congressional trips, it seemed fitting that Karen Pence, the wife of Vice President Mike Pence, announced that she was going back to her job as an elementary schoolteacher.

articles.headline: Why Jeff Bezos’ Divorce Should Worry Amazon Investors
articles.snippet: The Amazon chief’s split from his wife raises questions about the disposal of their enormous stake in the company he founded. Investors deserve answers.
articles.abstract: The Amazon chief’s split from his wife raises questions about the disposal of their enormous stake in the company he founded. Investors deserve answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos and his wife, MacKenzie, may be the first billionaire couple with a huge stake in an enormous technology company to announce their divorce.

articles.headline: Doug Jones Risks His Alabama Senate Seat Over the Shutdown and the Wall
articles.snippet: For Mr. Jones, the fight over the shutdown, in a state where President Trump is popular and many federal workers live, is a reminder that his party’s views are out of step back home.
articles.abstract: For Mr. Jones, the fight over the shutdown, in a state where President Trump is popular and many federal workers live, is a reminder that his party’s views are out of step back home.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — After Doug Jones scored an upset win in the Alabama Senate race in 2017, elated Democrats nationwide dreamed of winning in other deeply red corners of the country. Mr. Jones seemed to offer a model, rejecting labels like progressive or conservative and calling himself a “Doug Jones Democrat.”

articles.headline: Trump to Make ‘Major Announcement’ on Border as Democrats Sweeten Offer
articles.snippet: The actions are the first indications of possible movement over the partial government shutdown.
articles.abstract: The actions are the first indications of possible movement over the partial government shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats have added more than $1 billion in border-related spending to a package of funding bills that would reopen most of the government, even as President Trump said he would have a “major announcement” on Saturday about the border and the shutdown stalemate.
